sections.title: Build Your Safety Net
sections.subtitle: Understand the essential insurance coverages that protect your health, income, and assets

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: Why insurance is risk transfer and how it fits into your financial plan
The core policies every household should evaluate first
How to match coverage levels to your real-world exposure
Red flags that signal you are underinsured or overpaying

sections.title: Insurance Is Controlled Risk
sections.content: Insurance exists to shield you from financial shocks that would otherwise derail your goals. By paying a premium, you transfer catastrophic risk to an insurer with deeper pockets. The key is to insure against events that would be devastating—not the ones you can comfortably cash-flow.

points.title: Health Insurance
points.description: Medical debt is a leading cause of bankruptcy. Even high-deductible plans cap your worst-case costs and grant access to in-network pricing.

points.title: Disability Insurance
points.description: Your income is your biggest asset. Long-term disability coverage replaces a portion of your paycheck if illness or injury prevents you from working.

points.title: Life Insurance
points.description: Term life protects dependents from the loss of your income. Match coverage to outstanding debts, future college costs, and household living expenses.

points.title: Liability Insurance
points.description: Auto and homeowners policies include liability limits, but an umbrella policy adds $1–5 million in extra protection for lawsuits and major accidents.

sections.title: Rule of Thumb
sections.content: If replacing something would set you back more than six months of expenses, you likely need insurance for it.

sections.title: Spotting Coverage Gaps
sections.content: Review employer benefits, spouse coverage, and personal policies together. Look for overlapping protection (you may be double-paying) and areas with zero coverage. Self-employed professionals often overlook disability insurance; renters frequently skip renters insurance assuming the landlord covers their belongings—spoiler alert: they do not.

sections.title: Right-Sizing Your Policies
sections.content: Each policy has levers—deductible, coinsurance, maximum benefits—that affect both premium cost and out-of-pocket exposure. Raise deductibles when you have an emergency fund to self-insure minor claims. Boost liability limits if you have assets or future income worth protecting. Compare term lengths and riders on life insurance to match your family's dependency timeline.

sections.title: Coverage Audit Sprint
steps: List current policies with coverage limits, deductibles, and monthly premiums
Identify who or what each policy protects (your income, car, home, dependents)
Note any areas without coverage that would hurt if a loss occurred
Highlight policies with overlapping protection and evaluate if you can consolidate
Schedule a call with an independent agent to benchmark your current premiums

sections.title: Independent Agents Win
sections.content: Independent brokers can quote multiple carriers at once, helping you balance cost with coverage strength instead of pushing a single company's products.
